Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Georgia STEM Accessibility Alliance (GSAA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Georgia and Georgia Institute of Technology are collaborating partners with University of in a proposal to create the Georgia STEM Accessibility Alliance (GSAA). GSAA aims to establish an alliance between Georgia Institute of Technology, the University of Georgia, Georgia Perimeter College and three public secondary school districts. All project activities support the goal of increasing the postsecondary STEM degree and career attainment of individuals with disabilities. The GSAA?s goals relate to increasing the number of secondary students with disabilities (SWD) enrolling in STEM postsecondary classes and majors, increasing the retention and graduation rates of individuals with disabilities in postsecondary STEM majors, and increasing successful entry rates of GSAA students into STEM graduate programs. A distinctive feature of GSAA is the use of a virtual world as the primary service-delivery model. The use of virtual mentoring and teaching, social networking, academic support, transition assistance, and preparation of instructions will be the primary interventions utilized in GSAA. GSAA goals are:

Goal 1: Develop and evaluate GSAA intervention technologies and materials in Year 1 for use in Years 2-5. All modular materials will be made available via the Virtual Learning Reserves, one Reserve for secondary students and faculty and one for post-secondary students and faculty.

Goal 2: Increase the number of secondary SwD (40/per year/140 total) participating in the GSAA STEM mentoring and virtual world STEM activities and entering STEM postsecondary programs in two-year colleges, technical colleges or university partner institutions (50% of participants, or 20 per project year, 80 total). Entering is defined as matriculating with a stated major in a STEM-related field.

Goal 3: Increase retention in STEM majors by 180 students (baseline of 2,479 SWD, 723 SWD with declared STEM majors) and number of students graduating with STEM degrees (associates, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees) by 10 students from 2007 baseline (baseline of 94 students) in GSAA?s two-year college and university partner institutions through peer and faculty virtual and mentoring activities, evidence-based STEM learning practices, UDL solutions, and professional development initiatives.

Goal 4: Increase the entry of GSAA STEM graduates (associates, baccalaureate and graduate) into STEM graduate programs by 10 per year from baseline measures (71 students) in Years 2-5.

The project will implement interventions to support SWD as they cross three critical academic junctures: high school to two-year college; two-year to four-year college; and undergraduate education to graduate education or employment. GSAA activities include:
1. Creating a mentoring/training island in the virtual world of Second Life and integrating social networking tools to all participants year-round mentoring experiences;
2. Providing evidence-based STEM learning strategies with application of skills to STEM content via STEM Learning Seminars and Virtual Learning Communities for SWD;
3. Enhancing the STEM faculty and staff ability to educate SWD using web-based and Second Life training modules to provide core professional training and development;
4. Providing transition preparation and ongoing support to develop self-advocacy and academic skills essential for SWD to succeed in STEM secondary and postsecondary institutions.

Work by internal and external/independent evaluators will provide formative and summative evaluation for the project which will provide evidence for the GSAA model. Dr. Tom McKlin of The Findings Group will provide external evaluation services to the project. Virtual world development and maintenance will be provided by Vesuvius, Inc.

The project will develop materials for replicating the model nation-wide at secondary and postsecondary institutions. Recruiting processes, participant training methods, evaluation feedback instruments, and outcome measures will be formalized so that they can become easy to use for scale-up. GSAA materials and resources will be easily available via the Web to other institutions that seek to replicate the project model. GSAA will seek to apply scale-up first to other Alliances. Once this has been measured and documented, the project will apply efforts to scale up to other organizations outside of this funding directorate

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Georgia STEM Accessibility Alliance (GSAA) was a pioneering initiative for providing STEM access to secondary and postsecondary students with disabilities. The collaborative project, entitled BreakThru, involved The University of Georgia and the Georgia Institute of Technology. The project was an innovative and inclusive virtual mentoring model that combined social networking and virtual worlds to help adolescent and adults with disabilities pursue careers in STEM fields. BreakThru developed a scalable model, incorporating virtual resources and virtual mentoring to transform learning practices in STEM. The project identified the factors that generate persistence in STEM programs, and used this information to develop practices that enhanced progress for students with disabilities.

 

Excellence and equity are inextricably linked, but these descriptors can only be realized if underrepresented groups receive a larger proportion of STEM degrees. Access to learning depends on an understanding of the cognitive, affective, and language processes that influence different learning demands. Responding to this, the BreakThru model evaluated the effectiveness of personalized learning environments, virtual mentoring, social networking tools and universal design principles, ultimately providing adolescents and adults with disabilities greater access and support and a more equal footing when entering STEM careers.

 

BreakThru was a five-year program providing virtual mentoring to high school, 2-year post-secondary, and 4-year post-secondary students with the primary focus of adding more persons with disabilities to the STEM education and career pipeline. The project originally targeted 4-year post-secondary STEM students with disabilities at Georgia Tech and the University of Georgia along with high school students in three school districts in Georgia. During the second year, the program extended its services to Georgia Perimeter College, an institution primarily supporting 2-year post-secondary students.

 

BreakThru sought to increase the likelihood that students with disabilities persist in STEM by increasing students’ self-determination, self-advocacy, and positive math and science efficacy. The program demonstrated broad success at using virtual mentoring to increase self-advocacy for both secondary and postsecondary students. In particular, female participants showed greater pre-to-post gains in self-advocacy than male students, and students with cognitive and psychological disabilities showed significantly greater gains in self-advocacy than students with physical disabilities. For the STEM aspirations construct, minority students demonstrated greater gains than majority student. Further, 2-year post-secondary students may be in greatest need of aspirations to persist intervention since they come into the program with lower aspirations to persist than their 4-year post-secondary counterparts.

 

As for program dosage, 2-year post-secondary students remained in the program slightly longer than high school students. The data indicated that the longer a student remained in the program, the greater were their gains in positive math efficacy. Importantly, increases in positive science and math efficacy were the strongest predictors of changing students’ intentions to persist in STEM. That is, a program that emphasized the perception that science and math are interesting, enjoyable, and useful for one’s career stands a greater chance of increasing students’ intentions to persist in STEM.

 

Finally, the quality and quantity of the mentor-mentee relationship was positively correlated with student growth over time in self-determination, self-advocacy, positive science and math efficacy, and aspirations to persist in STEM (see Figure 8). That is, the greater the quality  and amount (quantity) of the mentor-mentee relationship, the more likely students were to report growth in these critical areas. It is important to note that perceptions of mentoring support (i.e., quality and quantity of mentoring) were very positive across the lifespan of the program. Likewise, the quality of mentoring support was rated high regardless of demographic group or program dosage.

 

Overall, the program was of the greatest benefit to female students, minority students, students with cognitive and psychological disabilities (as opposed to physical disabilities), and 2-year post-secondary students. Arguably, one promising direction for the next iteration of an eMentoring program targeting students with disabilities could be 2-year post-secondary institutions.
